question.title: Eclipse Plugin Get Code from Current Open File

node.contents: How can I get the code from the current open file in Eclipse returned in a String or String[]? I need this for a plugin I'm making.

astNode.text: How can I get the code from the current open file in Eclipse returned in a String or String[]? I need this for a plugin I'm making.

node.contents: Let's say I have the following code:

astNode.text: Let's say I have the following code:

elements.contents: public class HelloWorld { public static void main(String[] args) { System.out.println("Hello, world!"); } }

units.rawText: public class HelloWorld { public static void main(String[] args) { System.out.println("Hello, world!"); } }

node.contents: If I have HelloWorld.java open, how do I get that code returned in a String[]? The String[] would contain:

astNode.text: If I have HelloWorld.java open, how do I get that code returned in a String[]? The String[] would contain:

node.contents:
• "public class HelloWorld {"
  • "public static void main(String[] args) {"
  • "System.out.println("Hello, world!");"
  • "}"
  • "}"

node.contents:
`The method getAdapter(Class
<ifile>
 ) is undefined for the type IEditorInput`
</ifile>

astNode.text:
`The method getAdapter(Class
<ifile>
 ) is undefined for the type IEditorInput`
</ifile>

node.contents: Also no class IFile and IOUtils.

astNode.text: Also no class IFile and IOUtils.

node.contents: IEditorInput implements the IAdaptable interface, so getAdapter() should be there. IFile is in org.eclipse.core.resources. IOUtils is a class in Apache Common libraries. You can convert the InputStream to a String using others methods if you prefer. Which version of Eclipse are you using/targeting ?

astNode.text: IEditorInput implements the IAdaptable interface, so getAdapter() should be there. IFile is in org.eclipse.core.resources. IOUtils is a class in Apache Common libraries. You can convert the InputStream to a String using others methods if you prefer. Which version of Eclipse are you using/targeting ?

node.contents: To add "org.eclipse.core.resources", import is NOT enough. You have to add it as a dependency in your plugin MANIFEST.MF

astNode.text: To add "org.eclipse.core.resources", import is NOT enough. You have to add it as a dependency in your plugin MANIFEST.MF

node.contents: I got all errors to go away. Btw, I'm using Indigo.

astNode.text: I got all errors to go away. Btw, I'm using Indigo.

node.contents: There is nothing to download, you already have it (it a basic component of Eclipse). Add it in the MANIFEST.MF `Require-Bundle` list. (this code snippet is working for indigo.)

astNode.text: There is nothing to download, you already have it (it a basic component of Eclipse). Add it in the MANIFEST.MF `Require-Bundle` list. (this code snippet is working for indigo.)

node.contents: This code does get the **file content** —which is what was asked for. In some cases, one might want the **editor content**, instead —that would be a different question, though. In both cases, there is the presumption that "code" means **text**, but, in general, neither a file nor editor necessarily have text.

astNode.text: This code does get the **file content** —which is what was asked for. In some cases, one might want the **editor content**, instead —that would be a different question, though. In both cases, there is the presumption that "code" means **text**, but, in general, neither a file nor editor necessarily have text.

node.contents: To get the currently edited file's content you can do something like that:

astNode.text: To get the currently edited file's content you can do something like that:

elements.contents: IWorkbenchPart workbenchPart = PlatformUI.getWorkbench().getActiveWorkbenchWindow().getActivePage().getActivePart(); IFile file = (IFile) workbenchPart.getSite().getPage().getActiveEditor().getEditorInput().getAdapter(IFile.class); if (file == null) throw new FileNotFoundException(); String content = IOUtils.toString(file.getContents(), file.getCharset());

units.rawText: IWorkbenchPart workbenchPart = PlatformUI.getWorkbench().getActiveWorkbenchWindow().getActivePage().getActivePart(); IFile file = (IFile) workbenchPart.getSite().getPage().getActiveEditor().getEditorInput().getAdapter(IFile.class); if (file == null) throw new FileNotFoundException(); String content = IOUtils.toString(file.getContents(), file.getCharset());
